ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Integration, series and sequences, and polar/parametric, standard Calc II topics. Develop skills of calculus that will be useful if you continue in math/econ/STEM.
Calculus 2 skills including finding volume, integrating, etc.

Techniques and applications of integration. Sequences and series. Parametric equations. Polar coordinates. Approximations and error bounds. Skills in learning math, studying, and test-taking. Self-advocacy and learning through different modalities (videos, lectures, packets, practice problems, review sessions, office hours).
critical thinking, problem solving

I developed a stronger foundation for mathematics, even beyond what I thought I knew in high school. I took AP Calculus BC and IB Higher Level Mathematics : Analysis, and I still learned quite a lot from this course. Would Reccomend to anyone who wants a stronger foundation in mathematics.
Skills in integration, series and sequences, areas, volumes, polar coordinates, and parametric equations.
This class was really effective in teaching me calculus. I feel like in expert in all of the topic that we learned.
I got better at reaching out for others and teachers for help. I learned how to structure my week around attending office hours and made weekly office hours a part of my routine.

Beyond expanding my knowledge of the math concepts that were taught in this class, I learned how to prepare effectively for major exams and midterms, which was a new skill for me to develop as a freshman. I was forced to advocate for myself and take responsibility for my learning.
I learned how to approach complicated concepts that I had never seen before by breaking them down into smaller steps and understanding each step individually before putting it all together.
I learned how to do complicated calculus questions and how to better study for calculus tests.
How to apply concepts of integrals and derivatives to other aspects of math like area and volume.

This class helped me learn concepts in math such as integrals, series, and parametric and polar equations. Beyond that, it helped me, think at a higher level in terms of math. I was better able to understand how to approach different problems and gain a strong conceptual groundwork for the topics we covered.
I think I was able to conceptualize Calculus better and have a stronger basis from which to undertake higher level math.
How to think and approach logically

I think this course was a great introduction to integral calculus. I feel well prepared for multivariable next semester. I also think it was a good introduction to college math. It was challenging. I think one thing me and my friends in the class still could have a better grasp of is how to evaluate especially challenging integrals. I think this course helped me begin to work in groups as well.
I developed key insight into calculus that helps gauge my capacity for math and help me choose my major

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A lot of topics get covered in very little time. So many concepts were on each exam, which made the class really stressful.

Rachel Diethorn is an excellent instructor. Her guided notes and teaching style are very helpful and she is able to simply difficult concepts. The class is taught and organized very well. The psets and exams are graded very thoroughly which is helpful for understanding things you did wrong, and Rachel's office hours are helpful. Some of the parts of this course meant for engagement like the explorations, professor stories, and learning strategies were not very useful to improving my learning.

The notes offered were great.

The pace of this course could be improved, it could go a little slower to make sure students have established foundational skills before moving on.

Strengths: Rachel Diethorn, the instructor! Rachel is an amazing math teacher. She always brings a perfect, productive, quirky energy to class. She explains every concept in a manner that is easy to understand, takes very thorough notes on an iPad that are projected during class and posted to Canvas, and makes herself very accessible to students in class and during office hours. This course offers peer tutoring sessions at night, office hours, and review sessions before exams for students seeking extra help. The problem sets are very effective for practicing concepts, and there are ample practice resources before each exam. The grading for this course, through Gradescope, is fair and clear, so it is easy to know how you are doing in the course as it progresses. While calculus might not be the most interesting subject for many students, Rachel gets the job done very well.
Weaknesses: The online "Explore" modules due before each class are not very helpful and are essentially busy work. Similarly, the "calculus stories" modules don't seem very relevant to the course.
great, Rachel is awesome. wish there were more practice Qs, the tests were pretty hard

Strengths: 
- Instructor (Rachel Diethorn)
- Material Covered

Weaknesses:
- It felt like there was a very abrupt jump in the level of content.

The strengths were the lesson packets. All of the lessons were well structured and helpful. I found it an awesome way to learn. The weakness were the pre-class quizzes. I found them largely unhelpful and a waste of time.
The medium sized classes helps to balance the lecture style with in class participation which works well with math.

I loved my section of this course because Rachel was an incredible professor: she was organized, straightforward, approachable, and humorous. I really appreciated how she assembled a packet of notes for each class period and walked us through the packet on her iPad with different colors. However, having spoken to some of my peers enrolled in the same course but different sections, I think there was a wide range of experiences depending on people's professors which may have put some students at a disadvantage.

The topics in the class were organized in a great manner because they built off of each other super well.  The class could be improved by providing examples in class that are as difficult as those that we see on the exams so that students feel more confident and prepared going into exams.
Some of the professors did not teach the material very well while others were great at teaching the materials.
Rachel is amazing.

This course was very well organized, and many helpful resources were made available by the professors. There were many opportunities to get extra help, and classes were engaging and interesting. I don't think there is much that could be improved about this class.
A strength is the many available resources for all kinds of material. A weakness can be the due dates and time especially for some assignments.

- other than rachel not very well taught and incredibly variable formprofessor to professor 
- did not feel like my work/effort was being valued or rewarded due to the grading scale 
- could have more flexibility with deadlines like in calc 3

Strengths: Rachel is amazing and helped so much and the way she taught the class was easy to follow

Weaknesses: calc 2 here is not meant for those who have limited knowledge of calc 2 so it feels very confusing and as if you cant build the skills if you dont already have previous knowledge
This course is taught very thoroughly and it made my understanding of the material rock solid by the end of the semester. The explore assignments were useful in preparing us for the material.

It was very well laid out. I think the number of resources that this course offers to students is a great help. The review sessions at the end of the term for the final exam were great. I think the main weakness is just student specific--I didn't find the class as engaging as I'd hoped but it could just be that the material wasn't as interesting to me.

One strength of this course that may be specific to my professor is the worksheets that she gave us which were very helpful for organization, especially for students who were working on paper. There were also a great amount of practice problems for each unit which was very helpful.
Some of the TAs created stigma regarding not doing well in the course making it difficult to seek help outside of class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not if they don't have to take it. The material is pretty difficult and the problem sets were really long. Also, we would be assigned a problem set even when we had an exam which was stressful.
Yes, especially with Rachel Diethorn. She makes everything very clear and is generally an extremely helpful instructor.
Good introduction to calculus 2

Yes, if you need it as a prerequisite, take MATH 115 with Rachel Diethorn. She is a fantastic math teacher, and you will come out of this course with a solid understanding of Calc II. Be careful signing up for sections of this course, because certain other instructors may be inexperienced. Rachel, however, organizes the course very well, gives very clear explanations of each concept, and provides thorough notes in class and online so that you will surely learn the material. The main graded elements are weekly problem sets of textbook problems, two midterms, and a final exam.
Yes, only if you sign up for Rachel's section. You have to do lots of work after each class to prevent falling behind
Yes. I feel that this course helped me develop a stronger mathematical mind, and I believe that this course could serve to be useful in the future.
I would recommend this course because it is a great class to learn calculus and somewhat low stress. As someone who enjoys math, I loved this course.
Yes, Rachel does a great job at making the course engaging and will always answer any question you throw at her.
Yes, I would. I found it to be the perfect balance of challenge and enjoyment, and as aforementioned, I really enjoyed Rachel as a professor.

Yes because I had not taken Calc BC in high school and felt that I was understanding concepts well despite that since the class is structured in a way that is inclusive of all levels of math exposure.
Yes, if they want an introduction to math at Yale.
Yes, with Rachel! She's amazing

For someone who needs a QR credit or just has to take this class, I would recommend this class. Rachel was a great professor and if I ever felt myself struggling with a topic, she always cleared things up. Various resources were available for clarification/extra help, and many practice problems were always provided to help prepare for an exam. I have no complaints about this class, it was much easier than expected and I never felt underprepared.
Yes I would. It was not too difficult to just focus primarily on learning as a result of the many available resources.
Students who need this class for a major should definitely take this and for anyone interested in gaining a stronger understanding of single variable calculus, this is a great class.
- if you have to take it take it with rachel
Yes
Yes. It's a good course for learning integral calculus and I feel well prepared for ENAS 151/MATH 120.
Yes,
No, I didn't like how it was taught and was constantly missing how certain things were done in America being an international.
Yes
